Show don’t tell: Wherever you can, show people what you are doing, don’t explain it to

be a lot of time sitting and learning, we want you to experience everything by doing!

collaborate. In this room there are so many people with different backgrounds and
experiences. Use each other to brainstorm and develop your businesses. Later on, you
will even collaborate with your customers or anyone else who would interact with your
product/service. Bring together innovators with varied backgrounds and viewpoints.

User research helps us to understand how people go about performing tasks and
achieving goals that are important to them.
It gives us context and perspective and puts us in a position to respond with useful,
simplified, and productive design solutions.
User research focuses on understanding user expectations, behaviors, needs, and
motivations through methodical, investigative approaches.
It helps us identify unarticulated needs and to fill in any gaps in our knowledge about our
users, context of use, challenges, and opportunities.
It also helps us to align our product and business strategy with the core needs and goals
of our users.
Insights are then used to ensure that all product design decisions do benefit the user.

Your research plan: Welcome back from your break. I hope you are feeling re-energized!
So, as we said before, we all have an idea of who our customers are and what they
want, but really, these are just assumptions. We might be right on some things, but we
probably don’t have the whole picture. That’s why it is so important to create a research
plan. To help us fill these gaps and give us more insights on what our customers need!
How will we do this? Through three research methodologies: Do, Look, and Listen.
Do is all about experiential learning. Putting yourself in the shoes of your customers.
Look is learning through observation. Trying to see the behaviors of your customers to
pinpoint needs and opportunities.
Listen is where we talk to our customers through user interviews. Here we hear from
them and try to get to the root of their problems and really understand their behaviors
and emotions.

20 minutes: Lecture + activity

DO is all about experiencing what your customers experience. In order to understand the
pains of your customers, you have to go through the process yourself. For the DO, tell
the story of one of IDEO's engineers:
IDEO is one of the leading companies in product development focusing on design
thinking methodology. IDEO was working on creating a new design for a stove in a third
world country. They wanted to design a solution for women to make cooking easier for
them. So what did they do? They went to the country and used the stove. They
experienced how people cooked every day and got to feel how those women felt using
that stove. The lesson in this story is that even if you are an expert, you have to go
through the same experience of your users to feel their challenges!
15 minutes: Activity - Immerse (DO)
Have participants partner up
Give each pair a task:
Go into the bathroom and wash your hands,
Walk around the space, get a book, and put it on the table in the kitchen,
Make a cup of tea
Do a lap around the space
Get a piece of paper and write directions to the bathroom
You can do anything, be creative!
One participant will close their eyes and try to complete the task, while their partner
guides them and makes sure they don’t run into things or hurt themselves
Then switch so that both people go through the process
DEBRIEF: How was that experience? What did it make you learn? How do you think it
would be to be blind in a space like this?
Now think, if you were to design a product for someone who was blind, what are some
things you would include? Think about what helped you accomplish the task. Was it
useful to hold onto things? Were sounds helpful? Did you like it when someone was in
front of you? What were things that frustrated you while you were “blind“, how could that
be fixed?
LESSON: It is important to walk in your customers shoes, especially if you are
developing a product for them. To see life from their perspective will allow you to truly
understand them and their needs
What are they doing?
How are they doing it?
Why do you think they are doing that?
LOOK
3 minutes: Lecture

Another form of research is observation. You can learn so much by just observing people
in their natural routine. While you are watching, take note of a few things:
What are they doing? What are their actual behaviors? List them step by step. Be detail
oriented.
How are they doing it? Are they doing something a little odd that needs further
explanation? Is it easy for them? Difficult?
Why do you think they are doing that? What are they trying to accomplish? What is the
end goal?
10 minutes: Activity
Observe (LOOK): What is this a picture of? What do you see?
Spend 5-10 minutes getting thoughts from people. Take the time to build up a story
about this person.
Write everyone's thoughts on the board
Remember to touch on the previous slides questions (what, how, why)
What do you see versus what do you think based on what you see?
LESSON: You can learn so much from just looking, taking a step back and trying to
figure out what you’re seeing, what you can learn from watching. Keep in mind that you
can only learn some things. You can see their actual behaviors. You can observe body
language and make assumptions about WHY they are doing it that way. If you can, get
some clarification and speak to the person to understand why they did it in that way.
Ask for stories
Talk about emotions
Ask why?
LISTEN
3 minutes: Lecture
The last research method we are going to cover is the User Interview. In a user
interview, you spend 2-30 minutes to speak with customers to hear from them about their
experiences. If you take the time to speak to customers, they will tell you everything you
would ever need to know about how to make a great product for them. They will tell you
what they like and don’t like, the challenges they have with existing solutions and even
more! You just have to listen!
“Tell me about the last time you…”
“What was the best/ worse...”
“Why is that?”
“Can you tell me more?”

LISTEN
5 minutes: Lecture + discussion
Be careful how you phrase questions. It is important that you don’t lead your customers
into saying what you want to hear. By doing this, your interview data will be useless. To
give you some example of bad interview questions:
Do you like my idea? People tend to be nice, chances are nobody would want you to feel
bad and tell you that you have a bad idea. By asking this, you invite people to say “yes, I
like your idea” even though it might not be true.
Would you buy this product? This is another question that is tricky and usually provides
you with false information. Again many people would be tempted to say “yes” or
“probably” to this question. The best way to test if people are willing to buy a product is
to see if they actually take out their wallet and try.
Do you have trouble with _____? By posing challenges for them, you are putting words
in their mouth. Maybe they do have trouble with that, but you want to hear it from them.
Maybe they are facing the challenge differently than you are. Allow them to share their
thoughts on their own. Don’t tell or suggest to people how they feel or behave.
Can you tell me how you normally ….. This question is ALMOST good; however, it is too
general. You don’t get any real information. If you ask for generalities (‘what is your
normal evening like?’) then you’ll get a false picture, it will be their ‘idealized’ evening.
You need to ask a question that allows people to give you a specific story that has real
emotions.
So what are good questions to ask? The questions ask for stories, evoke emotions, and
go deeper into their actual behaviors.
“Tell me about the last time you…” By asking this question, you are able to get very
specific information. They will have details about what they liked and didnt like, there
might be a timeline, etc... You will get very rich information with this question.
“What was the best/ worse...” By asking these questions, you are learning more about
what the person likes and doesn’t. As you develop your product, it is important to know
what your customers care about and what their problems are.
“Why is that?” and “Can you tell me more?” These questions are great for going deeper.
If your interviewee says something surprising or interesting, you should want to know
more about it. Don’t assume anything, ask them about their thoughts.
Ask why 5 times – keep asking why so that you get to the deeper meaning and emotion
behind decisions. Humans make decisions based on emotion, it’s important for you to
understand why your users/ customers make their decisions

5-10 minutes: Lecture + example
Explain all the steps that go into an interview. Here are some tips on what to ask in the
beginning, in the middle, and at the end of a user interview:
Beginning: In the beginning of the interview, you should ask opening questions to set
people at ease and build rapport. You should not ask about sensitive topics. Instead,
focus on setting the stage and bringing your interviewees on board so they’re
comfortable enough to be, and remain, open with you. What you do at this stage can
include the following:
Telling participants what topics will be covered
Telling participants how their data will be used
Asking innocuous questions such as what their role is in their organization
Asking concrete questions that are easy to answer
Middle: In the middle of the interview, you’re hitting high gear. Having established a
direct channel with your interviewees (the users), you move on and ask the bulk of your
questions, but maybe not in the order you had originally planned. Remember to:
Keep the flow of the conversation as natural as possible, but cover the topics you want
to cover.
Pick up on what participants have said earlier and get full replies to questions they have
only partially answered.
Steer participants back on track if they go too far off topic.
Show that you have been listening.
Go deeper where necessary
End: At the end of the interview, you wrap up in a way that makes participants feel as
though they have said what they wanted to say and that their answers are valuable. By
this point, you will have managed to tie up any loose ends on matters that had not been
clear before, and both you and they should be satisfied that the interview has brought all
the issues out into the open. Things you should do include:
Asking if there is anything participants would like to add.
Telling your participants what you are going to do with their data and what the value is
for them.
Thanking them for taking the time to help with your research. Above all, remember to
conduct a pilot study before you start approaching real-life participants and tackling
‘organic’ interview settings. Also, always be sensitive to the fact that people are different
and need different things!

5 minutes: Example
Have 2 trainers go through a User Interview. Show a good user interview and a bad one.
EMPATHY MAP
8 minutes: Brainstorm
So after your interview, you should reflect on and reorganize your information. We will do
this through an empathy map.
After you give the explanation of the empathy map, fill it in for the practice interview you
just had in front of the group (with the trainers). Have it be a conversation and write out
the answers as a group on the white board. As you discuss together, highlight some
information about each quadrant (no need to explain each point in detail!)
The Says quadrant contains what the user says out loud in an interview or some other
usability study. Ideally, it contains verbatim and direct quotes from research.
“I love Asiacell because I never have a bad experience.”
“I want something reliable.”
“I don’t understand what to do from here.”
The Thinks quadrant captures what the user is thinking throughout the experience. Ask
yourself (from the qualitative research gathered): what occupies the user’s thoughts?
What matters to the user? Pay special attention to what users think, but may not be
willing to vocalize. Try to understand why they are reluctant to share — are they unsure,
self-conscious, polite, or afraid to tell others something?
“This is really annoying.”
“Am I dumb for not understanding this?”
The Does quadrant encloses the actions the user takes. From the research, what does
the user physically do? How does the user go about doing it?
Refreshes page several times.
Shops around to compare prices.
The Feels quadrant is the user’s emotional state, often represented as an adjective plus
a short sentence for context. Ask yourself: what worries the user? What does the user
get excited about? How does the user feel about the experience?
Impatient: pages load too slowly
Confused: too many contradictory prices
Worried: they are doing something wrong
You might encounter inconsistencies — for example, seemingly positive actions but
negative quotes or emotions coming from the same user. This is when empathy maps
become treasure maps that can uncover nuggets of understanding about our user. It is
our job as UX professionals to investigate the cause of the conflict and resolve it.
Some of these quadrants may seem ambiguous or overlapping — for example, it may be
difficult to distinguish between Thinks and Feels. Do not focus too much on being

precise: if an item may fit into multiple quadrants, just pick one. The 4 quadrants exist
only to push our knowledge about users and to ensure we don’t leave out any important
dimension. (If you don’t have anything to put into a certain quadrant, it’s a strong signal
that you need more user research before proceeding in the design process.)
**This is important to do together because we consistently have trouble with the
entrepreneurs not understanding how to use the empathy map.

EXTREME USER
5 minutes: Lecture
When conducting user interviews, make sure to include extreme users. Who are the
people who use this product every day?
For example, if you are making a new cleat, you definitely want to talk to people who
play sports (kids, parents who buy them, university students, etc…), but you would
probably want to talk to people who LIVE in cleats too. Take professional athletes for
example, they know every part of their shoes because they wear them for hours every
day. They know about what they love and hate about them.
Let’s take another example. If we were designing a new type of seat in a car, who would
the extreme user be? --- allow them to answer. Taxi drivers live in their cars. All day long
they are sitting in the seats and probably know really specific details of what makes them
comfortable or not. They might even share ideas on how it could be better.
While creating your user research plan, make sure to include extreme users!
You will want to include at least 1-2 extreme users into your research plan.

------------------------------------
Notes about Extreme Users to help facilitate discussion, no need to explain them all:
When considering the user's needs in design, it’s very easy for a designer to fall into the
trap of designing for the first, average user they can think of.
Only by understanding the viewpoints of a full range of people is it possible to avoid the
pitfall of designing for yourself.
Through speaking to the extreme users and identifying their amplified needs, it can help
pull out more meaningful insights and thus gives the potential to push ideas in different
directions that you wouldn’t have previously explored.
This group of users can help spark creativity by introducing you to hacks and use cases
you wouldn’t have imagined.
In the hope of trying to please the mainstream, which is still a very diverse group, it’s all
too easy to end up designing something generic and easy to replicate.
An idea that suits an extreme user is more likely to please the mainstream users too.
By focusing on the extremes, you can find the highest priority issues. Most commonly,
the high priority issue is what motivates people to buy this thing, and what is keeping
them from buying this thing?
Extreme user's are most in-tune with their needs, emotions and behaviors when using a
product or service and can, therefore, articulate needs/challenges better.

Asking the user to design for you.

3 minutes: Remember!
Designing from your own experiences. You are not the user.
Remember you want to make sure they are talking, not you!
Don’t assume things, allow them to share their own experiences
Asking the user to design for you
Don’t ask your interviewer what they think the solution is
Don’t have them list features
YOU are the designer! You need to gather information from people to create the solution
that will best fit their needs. By asking others to design for you, you stunt your creativity
and can come up with generic solutions.
Asking the user to respond to your idea
Avoid asking the user if they like your idea. Any person will just say “yes, I like it” or “yes,
I will use/buy this”

In general, people are polite, so you shouldn’t trust what they say in that way. Make sure
the questions are framed in a way where you are just focusing on the challenges they
are facing and learning about how they are currently dealing with them.
You should NOT give an explanation of your idea in a user interview.

LISTEN
5 minutes: Lecture + discussion

Be careful how you phrase questions. It is important that you don’t lead your customers
into saying what you want to hear. By doing this, your interview data will be useless. To
give you some example of bad interview questions:
Do you like my idea? People tend to be nice, chances are nobody would want you to feel
bad and tell you that you have a bad idea. By asking this, you invite people to say “yes, I
like your idea” even though it might not be true.
Would you buy this product? This is another question that is tricky and usually provides
you with false information. Again many people would be tempted to say “yes” or
“probably” to this question. The best way to test if people are willing to buy a product is
to see if they actually take out their wallet and try.
Do you have trouble with _____? By posing challenges for them, you are putting words
in their mouth. Maybe they do have trouble with that, but you want to hear it from them.
Maybe they are facing the challenge differently than you are. Allow them to share their
thoughts on their own. Don’t tell or suggest to people how they feel or behave.
Can you tell me how you normally ….. This question is ALMOST good; however, it is too
general. You don’t get any real information. If you ask for generalities (‘what is your
normal evening like?’) then you’ll get a false picture, it will be their ‘idealized’ evening.
You need to ask a question that allows people to give you a specific story that has real
emotions.
So what are good questions to ask? The questions ask for stories, evoke emotions, and
go deeper into their actual behaviors.
“Tell me about the last time you made a decision based on price, convenience, or
long-term value.” By asking this question, you are able to get very specific information.
They will have details about what they liked and didnt like, there might be a timeline,
etc... You will get very rich information with this question.
“What was the best/ worst …” By asking these questions, you are learning more about
what the person likes and doesn’t. As you develop your product, it is important to know
what your customers care about and what their problems are.
“Why is that?” and “Can you tell me more?” These questions are great for going deeper.
If your interviewee says something surprising or interesting, you should want to know
more about it. Don’t assume anything, ask them about their thoughts.
Ask why 5 times – keep asking why so that you get to the deeper meaning and emotion
behind decisions. Humans make decisions based on emotion, it’s important for you to
understand why your users/ customers make their decisions
“What drives their choices—cost, reliability, or ease of access? Are there patterns in
what they prioritize?” Ask users open-ended questions to understand their behaviors.

Based on my review of the Five One Labs Ignite curriculum (pre-incubator) documents, I see both strengths and opportunities for integrating green elements in a way that aligns with the business-first approach suggested in the "Integrated Business Resilience Framework."

## Current State Analysis

The Ignite curriculum provides a solid foundation in design thinking, customer research, problem definition, ideation, and pitching. The updates already made to modules 2 (User Research), 4 (Market Research), 5 (Reframe), 6 (Creativity and Ideation), and 7 (The Pitch) show thoughtful integration of green elements, primarily focusing on:

1. Expanding user personas to include environmental values
2. Adding resource efficiency considerations to market analysis
3. Introducing cost and resource factors in customer journey mapping
4. Including efficiency criteria in idea evaluation
5. Adding impact-driven elements to pitch judging criteria

These changes are generally subtle and business-focused, which aligns well with the core principles in the framework document.

## Alignment Opportunities

Despite these improvements, there are several opportunities to better align the pre-incubator with the incubator program and strengthen the "greening" approach:

### 1. Consistent Framing & Terminology

The terminology varies across modules. For example, in some places we talk about "energy costs," in others "resource efficiency," and elsewhere "environmental factors." A consistent framing (like the "business resilience" framing used in the integration framework) would help create a coherent theme.

### 2. Progressive Introduction of Concepts

Currently, green elements seem somewhat isolated within individual modules rather than building upon each other. There's an opportunity to create a progressive learning journey where basic concepts introduced in early modules evolve into more nuanced applications in later ones.

### 3. Practical Tools Integration

The Business Efficiency Workbook and Risk Assessment Process tools appear in the incubator program but aren't mentioned in the Ignite pre-incubator. Simplified versions of these tools could be introduced earlier.

### 4. Success Stories & Examples

The curriculum would benefit from consistent use of case examples showing how efficiency and resource considerations create business value.

## Specific Improvement Recommendations

### Module 2: User Research
- Add a short exercise where participants identify one external factor (like energy reliability) that might affect their users' experience
- Introduce the concept of "no-regrets paths" mentioned in the framework

### Module 4: Market Research
- Connect the updated "Market Forces & Business Costs" slide to concrete examples of businesses succeeding through efficiency
- Add a simple exercise to identify one resource constraint that could affect their business

### Module 5: Reframe
- Strengthen the connection between persona values and business model in customer journey mapping
- When creating "How Might We" statements, include an optional exercise to formulate a statement related to operational efficiency

### Module 6: Creativity & Ideation
- Add "resource efficiency lens" as a formal ideation technique alongside "$0" and "What would Google do?"
- Introduce a simple version of the Business Efficiency Checklist as an idea evaluation tool

### Module 7: The Pitch
- Create a sample pitch deck that effectively incorporates resource efficiency as a competitive advantage
- Add guidance on addressing potential investor questions about operational resilience

## Implementation Approach

To implement these changes while maintaining the business-first approach:

1. **Focus on practical value**: Frame all green elements in terms of business benefits first (cost savings, competitive advantage, risk reduction) rather than environmental impact.

2. **Use local examples**: Where possible, reference local Iraqi businesses that have succeeded through resource efficiency.

3. **Provide options**: Present efficiency and resilience considerations as optional elements that entrepreneurs can incorporate if relevant, rather than mandatory components.

4. **Start small**: For first-time entrepreneurs, focus on 1-2 simple efficiency concepts rather than overwhelming them with complex frameworks.

Overall, the curriculum updates show a promising start toward "greening" while maintaining a business focus. With the adjustments suggested above, the pre-incubator could better prepare participants for the more advanced business resilience concepts introduced in the incubator program.
